rev.comment: copy chronology en masse as a first step
rev.diff:
Line 1: Line 1:   +
==Chronology of events==
  +
===Week 1 (October 10â16)===
  +
====October 10: Encampment begins====
  +
Occupy Oakland began at 4 p.m. on October 10, 2011, with a rally attended by hundreds of supporters. Occupy Oaklandâs first rally, in which they occupied Frank Ogawa Plaza, was held in tandem with [[Indigenous People's Day]], both as a statement of solidarity and an expression that this action firmly situated itself against colonialism and nation states.{{citation needed|date=October 2011}} A couple dozen protesters set up tents that evening.<ref>{{cite news|last=Kuruvila|first=Mattai|title=Occupy movement in Oakland, SF housing protest|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/10/10/BA5T1LFU78.DTL&feed=rss.bayarea|accessdate=October 18, 2011|newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle|date=October 11, 2011}}</ref>
  +   +
====October 14: Brief march during rush hour====
  +
Protesters participated in a short march from Frank H. Ogawa Plaza to the Oakland Police headquarters and back.<ref>{{cite news|last=Quintana|first=Sergio|title=Occupy Oakland holds short march during rush hour|url=http://abclocal.go.com/kgo/story?section=news/local/east_bay&id=8392891|accessdate=October 18, 2011|newspaper=KGO|date=October 15, 2011}}</ref>
  +   +
====October 15: Weekend support rally ====
  +
Around 2,500 people, including actor [[Danny Glover]], came out for a Saturday march and rally to show their support for Occupy Oakland.<ref>{{cite news|title=Organizers say thousands took part in Oakland rally|url=http://www.ktvu.com/news/29497557/detail.html|accessdate=October 18, 2011|newspaper=KTVU|date=October 15, 2011}}</ref>
  +   +
===Week 2 (October 17â23)===
  +
==== October 17: Visit by U.S. hikers freed from Iran====
  +
{{ external media
  +
| align = right
  +
| width =
  +
| video1= "[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iYPn1tlRF78 Raw Video: Freed Hikers Visit Occupy Oakland.]" Compilation of scenes as Shane Bauer, Joshua Fattal and Sarah Shourd speak at Occupy Oakland.<ref name="AP teargas Oct.25th">{{cite web |url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iYPn1tlRF78 |title=Raw Video: Freed Hikers Visit Occupy Oakland |date=October 17, 2011 |publisher=Associated Press |accessdate=October 29, 2011 }}</ref>
  +
}}
  +
On October 17, 2011, Sarah Shourd, Shane Bauer and Joshua Fattal â the [[2009â2011 detention of American hikers by Iran|three American hikers recently freed from an Iranian prison]] â made their first West Coast speaking appearance at Occupy Oakland, drawing an audience of around 300 people.
  +
<ref>{{cite news
  +
| url=http://www.mercurynews.com/top-stories/ci_19132953?nclick_check=1
  +
| title=Freed American hikers speak to Occupy Oakland on Monday night
  +
| newspaper=San Jose Mercury News
  +
| date=October 18, 2011
  +
}}</ref>
  +   +
==== October 18: Establishment of Snow Park camp====
  +
A second camp with about about two dozen people was set up on October 18, 2011, primarily because the Frank H. Ogawa Plaza site was running out of room.<ref>{{cite news|last=Alston|first=John|title='Occupy Oakland' takes over a second park|url=http://abclocal.go.com/kgo/story?section=news/local/east_bay&id=8396951|accessdate=October 23, 2011|publisher=KGO|date=October 18, 2011}}</ref>
  +   +
==== October 19: Health Department visit====
  +
The [[Alameda County]] Health Department visited the site on October 19, 2011, on the pretext of "upholding public safety", specifically whether conditions were sanitary and whether rats that had previously been living in bushes in the park had been present in the encampment. No evidence was found of a rat problem within the camp. County representatives offered some recommendations but no aid.
  +   +
There had also been reports of violence and illegal drug use.<ref name=Rats>{{cite news
  +
| last=Maher
  +
| first=Sean
  +
| title=Rats and drugs mar Occupy Oakland tent city, officials say
  +
| url=http://www.mercurynews.com/bay-area-news/ci_19139574
  +
| accessdate=October 23, 2011
  +
| newspaper=San Jose Mercury News
  +
| date=October 19, 2011
  +
}}</ref> Demonstrators pointed out that violence and drug use are not uncommon in Oakland.<ref>{{cite news
  +
| title=Health Dept. visits Occupy Oakland camp amid strife
  +
| url=http://www.ktvu.com/news/29533894/detail.html
  +
| accessdate=October 20, 2011
  +
| publisher=KTVU|date=October 19, 2011
  +
}}</ref>
  +   +
==== October 20: Notice to vacate====
  +
On October 20, 2011, after accommodating the demonstrators for 10 days, the City of Oakland published an official notice citing "violence, assaults, threats and intimidation", among other complaints, and, forbidding lodging overnight. In the following days, the city continued to issue daily notices of violations in the campsites.<ref>October
  +
[http://www2.oaklandnet.com/oakca/groups/cityadministrator/documents/procedure/oak031803.pdf 20], [http://www.indybay.org/uploads/2011/10/21/occupyoakland_arrestwarning_oak031873.pdf 21], [http://www.indybay.org/uploads/2011/10/22/occupyoakland_arrestwarning-ogawa_102211_oak031875.pdf 22], [http://www.indybay.org/uploads/2011/10/23/occupyoakland_arrestwarning-snow_102311_oak031877.pdf 23], [http://www.indybay.org/uploads/2011/10/24/occupyoakland_arrestwarning-ogawa_1024411_oak031895.pdf 24] 2011 City of Oakland notices</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=McCleese|first=Tihanna|title='Occupy Oakland' protesters given ultimatum|url=http://abclocal.go.com/kgo/story?section=news/local/east_bay&id=8400403|accessdate=October 21, 2011|publisher=KGO|date=October 20, 2011}}</ref> The demonstrators "appeared determined not to leave" and countered that "the rats, drug crimes, and violence in the area of 14th Street and Broadway went unchecked before they arrived." <ref name=not_going>{{cite news|last=Fagan|first=Kevin|title=Occupy Oakland says it's not going anywhere|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/10/21/BA6S1LKNVB.DTL&tsp=1|accessdate=October 22, 2011|newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle|date=October 22, 2011}}</ref>
  +
<!-- [[File:OccupyEverything-LiberateOakland.jpg|thumb|left|Poster announcing the October 22 march.<ref>[http://www.occupyoakland.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/10/OccupyEverything_LiberateOakland1.jpg Occupy Oakland Poster]. [http://www.occupyoakland.org Occupyoakland.org]. Accessed October 2011.</ref>]] Fair-use on commons is not allowed.-->
  +   +
==== October 22: Downtown Oakland mass march====
  +   +
On October 22, 2011, protesters marched without permit, from Frank H. Ogawa Plaza to Snow Park carrying signs including, "Tax Wall Street" and "Revolt for a life worth living." Along the way, some protestors entered a Chase Bank branch and ripped up hundreds of deposit slips and threw them in the air. A few protesters stayed to help clean up the deposit slips. After leaving Chase, they protested outside of a Wells Fargo branch before returning to Frank H. Ogawa Plaza.<ref>{{cite news
  +
| last=Kuruvila
  +
| first=Matthai
  +
| title=Occupy Oakland shuts streets, defy eviction order|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/10/23/MNUU1LL5KR.DTL
  +
| date=October 23, 2011
  +
| accessdate=October 25, 2011
  +
| newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle
  +
}}</ref>
  +   +
===Week 3 (October 24âOctober 30)===
  +
==== October 25: Police raid, closure of plaza, and downtown Oakland march====
  +
[[File:Occupy Oakland protesters Oct 30.png|thumb|right|300px|Protesters retreating down Broadway Blvd. from tear gas fired by Police during the evening showdown at Frank H. Ogawa Plaza.]]
  +
On October 25, 2011, following multiple violation notices from city officials, police officers in [[riot gear]] from various [[San Francisco Bay Area|Bay Area]] law enforcement agencies cleared both camp sites during the early hours of the day.<ref name=police_clear/> Police fired [[tear gas]] canisters at the protestors, allegedly in response to objects being thrown at them.{{citation needed|date=October 2011}} Protest organizers said that many of the troublemakers were not part of the Occupy movement.<ref>{{cite news
  +
| last=McKinley
  +
| first=Jesse
  +
| title=Some Cities Begin Cracking Down on 'Occupy' Protests.
  +
| newspaper=New York Times
  +
| url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/10/27/us/oakland-and-other-cities-crack-down-on-occupy-protests.html
  +
| accessdate=October 27, 2011
  +
| date=October 26, 2011
  +
}}</ref> Two [[MSN]] reporters described the raid was described as "violent and chaotic at times"<ref>{{cite news
  +
| last=Farooq
  +
| first=Sajid
  +
| title=Occupy Oakland Gets Shut Down
  +
| url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/45031758#.Tqb7mHLO02I
  +
| date=October 25, 2011
  +
| accessdate=October 25, 2011
  +
}}</ref> and resulted in over 102 arrests. The post-raid scene was described by reporters for [[Mercury News]] as looking like a "hurricane-struck refugee camp."<ref>{{cite news |last=Bender |first=Kristen |title=Early morning police raid ousts Occupy Oakland |url=http://www.mercurynews.com/bay-area-news/ci_19188591 |accessdate=October 25, 2011 |newspaper=San Jose Mercury News |date=October 25, 2011}}</ref> Spencer Mills rose to prominence for his live broadcast of the night's events.<ref>[http://www.mercurynews.com/breaking-news/ci_19278376]</ref>
  +
The Snow Park camp was dismantled later in the morning. Six protesters were arrested.<ref name=police_clear />
  +
{{ external media
  +
| align = left
  +
| width =
  +
| video1= "[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CpO-lJr2BQY Raw Video: Protesters Clash With Oakland Police.]" Compilation of events as Oakland Police fire tear gas and arrest protesters marching through downtown Oakland en route to Frank Ogawa Plaza.<ref name="AP teargas Oct.25th">{{cite web |url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CpO-lJr2BQY |title=Raw Video: Protesters Clash With Oakland police |date=October 25, 2011 |publisher=Associated Press |accessdate=October 26, 2011 }}</ref>
  +
| video2= "[http://www.ktvu.com/video/29587714/index.html RAW VIDEO: Ground footage of Occupy Oakland march and crowd dispersal.]" Demonstrators march down Broadway Blvd. and arrive at police barricades blocking entry to Frank Ogawa Plaza. Oakland Police issue warnings to disperse. Marine veteran Scott Olsen can be seen falling to the pavement at 3:15. A police officer throws a flash bang in the crowd attempting to aid Olson at 3:30.<ref name="KTVU teargas Oct.25th">{{cite web |url=http://www.ktvu.com/video/29587714/index.html |title=RAW VIDEO: Ground footage of Occupy Oakland march and crowd dispersal |date=October 25, 2011 |publisher=KTVU |accessdate=October 27, 2011}}</ref>
  +
|video3= "[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QngE6kKk8Lg Occupy Oakland video: Riot police fire tear gas, flashbang grenades.]" Oakland police fire tear gas against marchers attempting to reoccupy Frank H. Ogawa Plaza. Scott Olsen can be seen being evacuated at :58{{mdash}}1:23.<ref name="RT teargas Oct.25th">{{cite web |url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QngE6kKk8Lg |title=Occupy Oakland video: Riot police fire tear gas, flashbang grenades |date=October 25, 2011 |publisher=Russia Today |accessdate=October 26, 2011}}</ref>
  +
}}
  +
Later that day hundreds of protesters and supporters gathered in front of the main branch of the [[Oakland Public Library]] to march back to Frank H. Ogawa Plaza to reclaim the space. As the march progressed, the police fired [[tear gas]] canisters after a conflict in which protestors attempted to pass through an open police line and were hit with batons and arrested.<ref>{{cite news |last=Kuruvila |first=Matthai |title=Police tear gas Occupy Oakland protesters |newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle |date=October 25, 2011 |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/10/25/BAUB1LLTC9.DTL |accessdate=October 25, 2011}}</ref> The march continued around the city for about two hours, and then moved in on the plaza. Police issued a dispersal order which failed to move the crowd, and fired [[tear gas]], and [[beanbag round]]s. Projectiles shot from behind police lines could be seen exploding and producing loud explosions and bright flashes among the crowd, but Oakland police have denied the use of [[Stun grenade|flashbang grenades]] and say that these explosions came from [[M-80 (explosive)|M-80 firecrackers]] being thrown by protesters.<ref>{{cite news |last=Wollan |first=Malia |title=Police Fire Tear Gas at Occupy Protesters in Oakland |work=The Lede Blog |newspaper=The New York Times |date=October 26, 2011 |url= http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/10/26/police-said-to-fire-tear-gas-at-protesters-in-oakland-calif/?hp# |accessdate=October 26, 2011}}</ref> Protesters and reporters from
  +
''[[The Guardian]]'' have described these explosions as looking and sounding like flash-bang devices.<ref>{{cite news |last=Gabbatt |first=Adam |title=Occupy Oakland protests - Wednesday 26 October |work=live blog |publisher=[[The Guardian]] |location=United Kingdom |date=October 26, 2011|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/blog/2011/oct/26/occupy-oakland-protests-live?CMP=NECNETTXT8187 |accessdate=October 29, 2011}}</ref> After the ensuing panic protestors regrouped and moved in again. This time a few protestors initiated conflict by throwing a bottle across the police line,{{citation needed|date=October 2011}} to which police responded again with non-lethal projectile and chemical weapons including [[CS gas]] (a more potent form of [[tear gas]]).<ref name=palo/>
  +   +
Scott Olsen, a former [[United States Marine Corps|Marine]] and [[Iraq War]] veteran, and a member of [[Veterans for Peace]], suffered a [[bone fracture|skull fracture]] caused by a shooting [[projectile]] that witnesses believed was a tear gas or smoke canister fired by the police.<ref>{{cite news
  +
| last=Henderson
  +
| first=Peter
  +
| last2=Randewich
  +
| first2=Noel
  +
| title=Oakland protesters plan march, mayor apologizes |publisher=Reuters
  +
| date=October 29, 2011
  +
| url= http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/10/29/us-usa-wallstreet-protests-oakland-idUSTRE79R5LH20111029
  +
| accessdate=October 29, 2011
  +
| quote=Olsen, 24, [...], was struck in the head by a tear gas canister fired on Tuesday by police, protest organizers said.
  +
}}</ref> A video by protesters has surfaced showing the explosion of a flash-bang device thrown by one officer near protestors attempting to aid Olsen.<ref name="Guardian_Olsen">{{cite news
  +
| last=Gabbatt
  +
| first=Adam
  +
| title=Scott Olsen injuries prompt review as Occupy Oakland protests continue
  +
| newspaper=[[The Guardian]]
  +
| location=United Kingdom
  +
| date=October 26, 2011
  +
| url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/oct/26/scott-olsen-occupy-oakland-review
  +
| accessdate=October 29, 2011
  +
}}</ref> The [[Associated Press]] later reported that it was not known exactly what kind of object had struck Olsen or who had thrown or fired it, and that protestors had been throwing rocks and bottles.<ref>{{cite news
  +
| url=http://articles.boston.com/2011-10-26/news/30324625_1_protesters-police-officers-demonstrators
  +
| title=Iraq war vet injured during Oakland protests
  +
| publisher=Boston.com
  +
| date=October 26, 2011
  +
}}</ref> [[MSNBC]] aired footage of a protestor who admitted that protestors had thrown bottles and rocks at police before the police had started to use tear gas.<ref>http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eHlHiNEZ1wA</ref> ''[[The Guardian]]'' reported that a projectile found near where Olsen fell was a [[bean bag round]].<ref name="Guardian_Olsen"/> Olsen was rushed to the hospital by other protesters, who were shot at with unknown police projectiles while attempting to aid him. Doctors said that he was in [[medical state|critical condition]].<ref>{{cite news |author=Adam Gabbatt |title=Occupy Oakland: Iraq war veteran in critical condition after police clashes |publisher=The Guardian |date=October 26, 2011
  +
|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/oct/26/occupy-oakland-veteran-critical-condition |accessdate=October 29, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Marine Veteran Injured by Non-Lethal Rounds at Occupy Oakland |publisher=Veterans Today |date=October 26, 2011 |url= http://www.veteranstoday.com/2011/10/26/marine-veteran-injured-by-non-lethal-rounds-at-occupy-oakland/ |accessdate=October 26, 2011}}</ref> At least two other protesters were injured.<ref name=rt261011/> The [[American Civil Liberties Union]] and [[National Lawyers Guild]] are calling for an investigation into the use of excessive force by Oakland police.<ref name=return>{{cite news |last=Bender |first=Kristen |title=Occupy Oakland protesters return downtown to claim Frank Ogawa Plaza |url=http://www.mercurynews.com/ci_19197518 |accessdate=October 27, 2011 |newspaper=Oakland Tribune |date=October 26, 2011}}</ref>
  +   +
The Oakland Police department requested 500 officers from at least 17 other law-enforcement agencies to assist in the sweep and subsequent street skirmishes under "mutual aid" agreements. Agencies which are known to have participated include the [[Berkeley Police Department]], [[San Francisco Sheriff's Department]], [[Santa Clara County Sheriff's Office]], [[California Highway Patrol]], Solano County Sheriff's Office, [[University of California Police Department]], [[Alameda County Sheriff's Office]], and [[Palo Alto]] Police Department.<ref name=palo>{{cite news
  +
| url=http://www.paloaltoonline.com/news/show_story.php?id=23012
  +
| date=October 27, 2011
  +
| title=Palo Alto police involved in 'Occupy' incident
  +
| publisher=''Palo Alto Online''
  +
}}</ref><ref>{{cite news
  +
| url=http://www.baycitizen.org/occupy-movement/story/hunt-rubber-bullets-occupy-oakland
  +
| date=October 26, 2011
  +
| title=The Hunt for Rubber Bullets at Occupy Oakland
  +
| publisher=''The Bay Citizen''
  +
}}</ref>
  +
<ref>{{cite news
  +
| url=http://www.dailycal.org/2011/10/27/community-raises-concern-with-berkeley-police-ucpd-involvement-in-occupy-oakland/
  +
| date=October 27, 2011
  +
| title=Community raises concern with Berkeley police, UCPD involvement in Occupy Oakland
  +
| newspaper=''The Daily Californian''
  +
}}</ref>
  +   +
At this point, it appears that Oakland city officials, including Mayor [[Jean Quan]], were not aware of exactly what weapons were being used by these outside police agencies, including possibly [[rubber bullet]]s (which Oakland Police Chief Howard Jordan says were not used by the O.P.D.).{{Citation needed|date=November 2011}}
  +   +
====October 26: Frank Ogawa Plaza demonstration and general assembly====
  +
[[File:Occupy Oakland Nov2 Strike Poster.jpeg|thumb|right|Online poster for the November 2 strike.<ref>[http://www.occupyoakland.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/10/311066_268206476549289_100000798165569_697749_1512800417_n.jpg Occupy Oakland Strike Poster]. [http://www.occupyoakland.org Occupyoakland.org]. Accessed October 2011.</ref>]]
  +
More than a thousand protesters gathered peacefully at Frank H. Ogawa Plaza on October 26, 2011. Participants in the [[Occupy Wall Street#New York City General Assembly|general assembly]] (an open democratic meeting based on [[Occupy Wall Street]]'s New York general assembly), held in the plaza's amphitheater, agreed to organize a [[general strike]] for November 2.<ref name=return /> The Oakland Police Department released a statement confirming the use of [[bean bag round]]s.<ref>{{cite news
  +
| last=Flock
  +
| first=Elizabeth
  +
| title=Iraq veteran Scott Olsen now in 'fair' condition
  +
| work=blogPOST
  +
| publisher=[[Washington Post]]
  +
| date=October 27, 2011
  +
| url= http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/blogpost/post/occupy-oakland-veteran-scott-olsens-injuries-prompt-internal-police-review/2011/10/27/gIQAVrs1LM_blog.html
  +
| accessdate=October 29, 2011
  +
}}</ref>
  +   +
====October 27: Vigil for Scott Olsen, re-encampment of plaza, statement by mayor====
  +
At least 1,000 protesters held a candlelight vigil for Scott Olsen at Frank Ogawa Plaza.<ref>{{cite news
  +
| last=Dearen
  +
| first=Jason
  +
| title=Vigils for Injured Vet, Police Clear Tenn. Protest
  +
| url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory/wall-street-protesters-hold-vigils-injured-vet-14831926
  +
| accessdate=October 28, 2011
  +
| publisher=Associated Press
  +
| date=October 27, 2011
  +
}}</ref> The plaza was re-taken by protesters with about two dozen tents erected that evening. Mayor Jean Quan issued a statement urging non-violence and asked that there be no overnight camping; however, the city did not take steps to prevent the re-occupation.<ref>{{cite news
  +
| last=Bulwa
  +
| first=Demian
  +
| title=Some tents reappear at Occupy Oakland site
  +
| newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle
  +
| date=October 28, 2011
  +
| url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/10/28/MNHK1LN717.DTL
  +
| accessdate=October 28, 2011
  +
}}</ref> Scott Olsen's medical status was upgraded from "critical" to "fair" by doctors at Highland Hospital, although surgery was still being considered in order to reduce pressure on his brain.<ref>{{cite news
  +
| last=Gabbatt
  +
| first=Adam
  +
| title=Occupy Oakland - police under scrutiny Thursday 27 October
  +
| work=live blog |publisher=[[The Guardian]]
  +
|location=United Kingdom
  +
| date=October 27, 2011
  +
| url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/blog/2011/oct/27/occupy-oakland-police-live?INTCMP=ILCNETTXT3487
  +
| accessdate=October 29, 2011
  +
}}</ref> On October 30, Olsen's roommate Keith Shannon reported that doctors expect Olsen to make a full recovery.<ref>{{cite news |title= Injured Occupy Oakland protester should make full recovery, roommate says |first= Sean |last= Maher |url= http://www.mercurynews.com/bay-area-news/ci_19227978 |newspaper= [[San Jose Mercury News]] |date= 2011-10-30 |accessdate= 2011-11-01 |quote= An Iraq War veteran badly injured when police stormed an Occupy Oakland encampment last week is expected to make a full recovery, his roommate said Sunday. |archiveurl= |archivedate= |deadurl= }}</ref>
  +   +
====October 28: Michael Moore visits, rebuilding continues, solidarity march in Egypt====
  +
Documentary filmmaker [[Michael Moore]] spoke to a crowd of about 1,000 protesters. In the hour-long address, Michael Moore encouraged Occupy Oakland by saying, "We've killed despair across the country and we've killed apathy." <ref>{{cite news
  +
| title=Michael Moore: Occupy movement "killed apathy"
  +
| url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-201_162-20127435/michael-moore-occupy-movement-killed-apathy/
  +
| accessdate=October 29, 2011
  +
| publisher=CBS News
  +
| date=October 29, 2011
  +
}}</ref> Dozens of new tents have been erected in the plaza, including a medical tent provided and staffed by the [[California Nurses Association/National Nurses Organizing Committee|California Nurses Association]].<ref name= "Kuruvila 10-29-2011">{{cite news
  +
| last=Kuruvila
  +
| first=Matthai
  +
| title=Occupy Oakland: inspiration, frustration at return
  +
| url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/10/29/MN951LNTGB.DTL
  +
| accessdate=October 29, 2011
  +
| newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle
  +
| date=October 29, 2011
  +
}}</ref>
  +
Pro-democracy protesters in Egypt marched from Cairo's [[Tahrir Square]] to the U.S. Embassy in solidarity with Occupy Oakland.
  +
<ref>{{cite news
  +
| title=Egyptians March for Occupy Oakland
  +
| url=http://www.nbcbayarea.com/news/politics/132802458.html
  +
| accessdate=October 28, 2011
  +
| publisher=NBC Bay Area
  +
| date=October 28, 2011
  +
}}</ref>
  +   +
===Week 4 (October 31âNovember 6)===
  +
====October 31: Press conference====
  +
Representatives of Occupy Oakland held a press conference detailing plans for the general strike on November 2.<ref>{{cite news|title=Oakland braces for Occupy movement's call for general strike|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2011/11/oakland-braces-citywide-general-strike-.html|accessdate=November 1, 2011|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=November 1, 2011}}</ref>
  +   +
====November 1: Oakland police publish statement of concerns about Mayor====
  +
The Oakland Police Officer's Association issued an [http://www.opoa.org/uncategorized/an-open-letter-to-the-citizens-of-oakland-from-the-oakland-police-officers%E2%80%99-association/ open letter] to the citizens of Oakland expressing "confusion" about Mayor Quan's decision making.<ref>{{cite news|last=Fagan|first=Kevin|title=Oakland police union: 'We are confused' by Quan|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/11/01/BAOS1LP3SB.DTL&tsp=1|accessdate=November 2, 2011|newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle|date=November 2, 2011}}</ref> The open letter took issue with Mayor Quan's decision to allow public employees to participate in the upcoming general strike:
  +
<blockquote>[T]he Administration issued a memo on Friday, October 28th to all City workers in support of the âStop Workâ strike scheduled for Wednesday, giving all employees, except for police officers, permission to take the day off.
  +   +
Thatâs hundreds of City workers encouraged to take off work to participate in the protest against âthe establishment.â But arenât the Mayor and her Administration part of the establishment they are paying City employees to protest? </blockquote>
  +   +
====November 2: General strike====
  +
[[File:Oakland General Strike 2011-11-02.jpg|thumb|One of the marches to the Port of Oakland on Nov. 2, 2011]] Thousands of protesters gathered at Frank Ogawa Plaza to participate in rallies, marches, and teach-ins designed to empower citizens and to draw attention to economic inequity and corporate greed. <ref>{{cite news|title=California protesters shut down Oakland port|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-15568057|accessdate=November 2, 2011|date=November 2, 2011|publisher=BBC News}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=California protesters shut down Oakland port|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/nov/02/occuply-oakland-general-strike-live|accessdate=November 3, 2011|date=November 2, 2011|publisher=The Guardian News Blog}}</ref> The last general strike in the United States was in Oakland in 1946. Local unions expressed solidarity for the [[strike action|strike]] including Oakland's largest union, [[Service Employees International Union|Service Employees International Union]] Local 1021, Oakland Education Association, [[International Longshore and Warehouse Union|International Longshore and Warehouse Union]] Local 10, and [[United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America|United Brotherhood of Carpenters]]. While none of the unions were officially on strike, many urged their members to take a personal day, vacation day or to participate after work. <ref>{{cite news|last=Gee|first=Robyn|title=Teachers, Service Workers Support Oakland's Strike Without Striking|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/turnstyle/teachers-service-workers_b_1071604.html|accessdate=November 6, 2011|newspaper=Huffington Post|date=November 2, 2011}}</ref>
  +   +
While most of the day-time activities were peaceful, Oakland Police chief Howard Jordan reported that a small group of "anarchists" vandalized a [[Whole Foods]] storefront, and broke windows and [[ATM]]s of [[Bank of America]] and [[Wells Fargo]] banks in the afternoon. <ref>{{cite news|title=Occupy Oakland General Strike Shuts Down Port; Anarchists âBent On Creating Problemsâ|url=http://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2011/11/02/general-strike-protesters-shut-down-port-of-oakland/|accessdate=3 November 2011|publisher=CBS San Francisco|date=2 November 2011}}</ref> <ref>[http://www.mercurynews.com/top-stories/ci_19246904 At least 4,000 are at the gates to the Port of Oakland]</ref> Many buildings were vandalized, including some businesses that displayed signs of support for the General Strike. After the incidents of vandalism, members of Occupy Oakland organized to guard local businesses, board up broken windows, and clean graffiti caused by the [[black bloc]] vandals. Oakland mayor Jean Quan described the vandals as "a small and isolated group" that "shouldn't mar the overall impact of the demonstration and the fact that people in the 99 percent movement demonstrated peacefully and, for the most part, were productive and very peaceful."<ref>[http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=%2Fc%2Fa%2F2011%2F11%2F03%2FBACM1LQ5FU.DTL]</ref>
  +   +
Thousands of protesters marched from Frank Ogawa Plaza to the [[Port of Oakland]], the fifth busiest port in the United States, in two separate groups leaving the plaza at 4:00 pm and 5:00 pm. The number of protesters marching to the port has not been confirmed. While police estimate 7,000 people marched, local organizers <ref>{{cite news|title=Video Report from Streets of Oakland: First General Strike in City Since 1946 Shuts Down Major Port|url=http://www.democracynow.org/seo/2011/11/3/video_report_from_streets_of_oakland|accessdate=November 6, 2011|publisher=Democracy Now|date=November 3, 2011}}</ref> and participants <ref>{{cite news|last=Abraham|first=Zennie|title=Occupy Oakland Strike Draws 100,000; Violence Caused By 100|url=http://blog.sfgate.com/abraham/2011/11/03/occupy-oakland-strike-draws-100000-violence-caused-by-100/|accessdate=November 6, 2011|newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle - Blog}}</ref> put the number somewhere between 20,000 and 100,000. As protesters completely filled Middle Harbor Road, the main road leading to the port, all truck traffic entering or exiting the port was halted. Port operations were "effectively shut down" a couple hours later. <ref>{{cite news|title=Occupy Oakland throng closes down port|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/11/03/MN8Q1LPI1J.DTL|accessdate=November 3, 2011|date=November 2, 2011|newspaper=The San Francisco Chronicle}}</ref> During the march a frustrated driver of a Mercedes struck two pedestrians who were taken to the hospital with minor injuries. The driver was questioned by BART police and released. <ref>{{cite news|last=Kuruvila|first=Matthai|title=Mercedes hits 2 Occupy Oakland protesters|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/11/03/BA5G1LQ06S.DTL|accessdate=November 6, 2011|newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle|date=November 3, 2011}}</ref>
  +
====Night of Nov 2: Plaza Arrests====
  +
Later in the evening, a group of protesters took over a vacant building that once served as the headquarters of the Traveler's Aid Society, a non-profit organization that provided services to the local homeless population. Police soon arrived to break up the protesters gathered outside of the building. Some protesters fled while others set a barricade on fire. <ref>{{cite news|last=Loftis|first=Emily|title=Occupy Oakland shuts down port|url=http://www.salon.com/2011/11/03/occupy_oakland_shuts_down_port/|accessdate=November 4, 2011|newspaper=Salon|date=November 3, 2011}}</ref> Police used teargas and flash bangs to try to clear protesters. At least one man was carried away injured after protesters said he was shot in the leg by a rubber bullet. <ref>{{cite news|title=Occupy Oakland general strike â Thursday 3 November|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/blog/2011/nov/03/occupy-oakland-general-strike-live#block-13|accessdate=November 3, 2011|date=November 2, 2011|newspaper=The Guardian}}</ref> Clashes continued past midnight. 103 people were arrested.
  +
{{ external media
  +
| align = left
  +
| width =
  +
| video1= "[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CQl0g2Rqyfs CA Violence: RT footage from 'occupied' Oakland]" Compilation of events as Oakland police begin using tear gas to disperse crowds, while protesters retreat from the police line, treat those effected by gas, break windows at nearby businesses, or provide film interviews.
  +
| video2= "[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MnBGaru-nxQ More RT footage: Riot cops tear gas Occupy Oakland strike]" Further compilation of events.
  +
| video3= "[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=I0pX9LeE-g8 Shot by police with rubber bullet at Occupy Oakland]" Filmed by Oakland resident Scott Campbell, moments before being shot by an Oakland Police officer.
  +
}}
  +
Shortly before 1am, Oakland resident and anarchist Scott Campbell was shot by police using a [[Non-lethal_weapon#Ammunition|less-lethal round]] while he was filming a stationary line of police in riot gear. The apparently-unprovoked shooting was documented by the resulting point-of-view video from Campbell's own camera.<ref>[http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-201_162-57321440/experts-occupy-vid-shows-excessive-force/ Experts: "Occupy" video shows excessive force]</ref> Geoffrey Alpert, a criminal justice professor from the University of South Carolina said watching a video of the incident left him "astonished, amazed and embarrassed" and that "unless there's something we don't know, that's one of the most outrageous uses of a firearm that I've ever seen."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/top-stories/ci_19284774|accessdate=Nov 7, 2011}}</ref>
  +   +
Kayvan Sabeghi, a former [[United States Army Rangers|U.S. Army Ranger]] who served in the [[Iraq War]] and the [[War in Afghanistan (2001âpresent)|War in Afghanistan]], was seriously injured while being arrested by police that evening. He was walking away from the late evening protest when he was stopped by police. <ref>{{cite news|last=Gabbatt|first=Adam|title=Occupy Oakland: second Iraq war veteran injured after police clashes|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/nov/04/occupy-oakland-second-veteran-injured|accessdate=November 6, 2011|newspaper=The Guardian|date=November 4, 2011}}</ref> The organization [[Iraq Veterans Against the War]] issued a statement saying that "police struck Sabeghi with nightsticks on his hands, shoulders, ribs and back, and that in addition to a lacerated [[spleen]] he suffered from internal bleeding." After 18 hours of being denied medical treatment while in police custody he was transferred to [[Highland Hospital (Oakland, California)|Highland Hospital]] and put into the intensive care unit. <ref name=kayvan_reuters>{{cite news|last=Randewich|first=Noel|title=Army veteran injured in Oakland clashes with police|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/11/05/us-protests-oakland-veteran-idUSTRE7A37A820111105|accessdate=6 November 2011|newspaper=Reuters|date=4 November 2011}}</ref> <ref>{{cite news|title=Kayvan Sabeghi Injured: Second Iraq war vet hurt during Oakland clash with police|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/11/05/kayvan-sabeghi-injured_n_1077806.html|accessdate=5 November 2011|newspaper=Huffington Post|date=5 November 2011}}</ref>
  +   +
Journalist Susie Cagle was arrested in the early hours of November 3, jailed, and ultimately charged with a misdemeanor. Cagle subsequently reported having observed mistreatment of protestors during their imprisonment.<ref>[http://www.alternet.org/story/152990/police_state_in_oakland_one_reporter%27s_arrest_contradicts_official_story/?page=entire]</ref>
  +   +
====November 4: City Council meeting====
  +
The Oakland City Council held a five hour meeting to consider a resolution by council member [[Nancy Nadel]] in support of the Occupy Oakland encampment. The council heard over 100 people speak about the positives and negatives of Occupy Oakland. The vote on the resolution was postponed until the November 15 city council meeting. <ref>{{cite news|title=Tense Meeting Reveals Deep Divisions over Occupy Oakland|url=http://www.baycitizen.org/occupy-movement/story/tense-meeting-reveals-deep-divisions/|accessdate=November 5, 2011|publisher=The Bay Citizen|date=November 4, 2011}}</ref>
  +   +
====November 5: Protest at Wells Fargo====
  +
A downtown Oakland Wells Fargo branch closed for business because of the roughly 100 immigrant rights protesters who marched from Occupy Oakland's encampment to protest the bank's connection to companies that run [[Immigration detention in the United States|immigrant detention centers]]. <ref>{{cite news|last=Wohlsen|first=Marcus|title=Protesters close down Oakland Wells Fargo branch|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/n/a/2011/11/05/state/n134250D33.DTL|accessdate=November 5, 2011|newspaper=AP - San Francisco Chronicle|date=November 5, 2011}}</ref>
  +   +
===Week 5 (November 7âNovember 13)===
  +
====November 7: $20,000 from [[Occupy Wall Street]]====
  +
On November 7, Occupy Oakland deposited $20,000 for "urgent medical and legal expensive" from Occupy Wall Street. Pending formation of a non-profit, the money was held in the accounts of its attorneys. Upon learning that the account was held by Wells Fargo, the Oakland General Assembly subsequently released a statement stating that the funds would be transferred to a local credit union.<ref>[http://www.sfexaminer.com/local/2011/11/occupy-oakland-makes-20k-deposit-wells-fargo Occupy Oakland makes $20K deposit at Wells Fargo], San Francisco Examiner, November 8, 2011</ref><ref>[http://www.occupyoakland.org/generalassembly/committees/ Occupy Oakland General Assembly statement on $20,000 donation]</ref>
  +   +
====November 9: Oakland City Council press conference and counter-demonstration====
  +
On November 9, five members of the Oakland City Council, Desley Brooks, Ignacio De La Fuente, Pat Kernighan, Libby Schaaf, Larry Reid, and an accompanying group of two dozen clergy and Oakland small business owners, held a press conference near [[Children's Fairyland]], calling for the immediate eviction of Occupy Oakland. The group alleged that the ongoing protest had harmed the economy of downtown Oakland, and cited reports of fire hazards in the camp. Upon learning of the conference, Occupy protesters interrupted Larry Reid's speech with chants, including "we are the 99 percent of Oakland." The council members and business owners than begin counter chanting "Occupy Oakland must go." Brooks, who had previously supported the protest, criticized the protesters for obstruction of the council's freedom of speech, saying, "This display was indicative of the problem with Occupy Oakland." A protester countered, "We cannot have dialogue when their statement is immediate eviction."<ref>Kuruvila, Matthai [http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/11/09/BAH61LSRPF.DTL Occupy protesters shout down Oakland council] ''San Francisco Chronicle'' November 9, 2011</ref>
  +   +
While the camp was emptied of most of its protesters, Jean Quan used the opportunity to enter the Ogawa Plaza camp of 180 tents and held a small meeting with the remaining protesters. She later commented that she called upon the protest to disassociate itself from "violent demonstrators", and said of the meeting, "I hope that was a good beginning."<ref>Hollyfield, Amy [http://abclocal.go.com/kgo/story?section=news/local/east_bay&id=8424668 Protesters, city headed for showdown in Oakland] ''ABC KGO 7'' November 9, 2011</ref>
  +   +
====Night of Nov 9: OccupyCal at UC Berkeley====
  +
Oakland General Assembly had previously passed a statement of solidarity with the OccupyCal protest at the University of California Berkeley. In the evening of November 9, law enforcement from Oakland Police, Alameda County Sheriff, and UC Police attempted to evict the members of OccupyCal from their encampment on the campus. In line with the earlier general assembly vote, members of Occupy Oakland joined in the Berkeley protest.
